g.text: 2019 The Authors. Published by WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
element cadmium, have hindered sales of those products in
some markets. InP-based QDs have been explored in the Sam-
sung QD TVs, due to the reduced toxicity and thus the unre-
stricted use of this material in consumer products in most
markets. However, indium is a rare element which is already
heavily used in other applications, and the color saturation of
InP QDs does not match that of CdSe QDs, due to their wider
emission linewidth. Lead halide perovskite nanocrystals
recently emerged as another promising light-emitting material
for displays, due to their ease of synthesis and exceptionally
narrow emission linewidths. Unfortunately, the large degree
of ionic character in these materials limits their stability, this
in addition to the presence of toxic Pb, may become a limiting
factor for commercialization. For the older class of II-VI mate-
rials, both 1D QRs and 2D nanoplatelets offer an added advan-
tage for LCDs, because they can emit linearly polarized light.
At the same time, those anisotropic non-spherical nanocrystals
require a proper processing, as they need to be assembled with
a high degree of orientational order so as to gain the benefit of
the linear polarized emission as an ensemble.
This review offers a comprehensive discussion of the poten-
tial use of down-conversion colloidal nanomaterials for LCD
applications. After introducing basic optical properties of QDs
and QRs, we will consider various assembly strategies for QRs,
with a particular emphasis on assembling anisotropic mate-
rials to obtain polarized emission in the ensemble. Finally,
we will present QD- and QR-based device architectures and
highlight several concepts that emerge from the wide variety
of light-emitting materials that are now feasible for these
The term âquantum dotâ has been given to spherical
(or quasi-spherical in case of wurtzite materials such as CdSe)
semiconductor nanocrystals because they exhibit quantum
confinement effect, for nanoparticles with radii smaller
than the Bohr radius of the bulk exciton.
bandgap of the QDs becomes size-dependent, increasing with
a decreasing radius due to the increased interaction energy
between the hole and the electron. As an example, when
the radius of CdSe QDs decreases from 4.15 to 0.60 nm, the
photon energy of the first absorbance peak,
1.88 to 3.02 eV (the bandgap energy of bulk CdSe is
eV), and the emission color changes from red to blue.

and photonic devices. He is a
senior member of the Society for Information Display (SID),
at the University of Hamburg, Germany, from 1995 to
2002. During 2002â2009, he was a lead staff scientist at
the Department of Physics of the Ludwig-Maximilians-
University in Munich, Germany, where he completed his
habilitation in experimental physics. His research focuses
on the synthesis and optical spectroscopy of colloidal
semiconductor and metal nanocrystals and their use for
at CAS-IPE in Beijing and in
and later was a senior lecturer, Rutherford Discovery
Fellow, and PI in the MacDiarmid Institute at Victoria
University of Wellington. His research interests include
nanocrystals, and quantum dots, especially perovskites,
in optoelectronic devices, including memristors, batteries,
